SVGElement.summary: All of the SVG DOM interfaces that correspond directly to elements in the SVG language derive from the SVGElement interface.

remarks.para:
-HTML data-* attribute
-SVG {{SVGAttr("data-*")}} attribute
-Using custom data attributes in HTML

SVGElementAttributeStyleMap.summary: The attributeStyleMap read-only property of the interface returns a live object that contains a list of style properties of the element that are defined in the element's inline style attribute, or assigned using the property of the interface via script.

remarks.para: Shorthand properties are expanded. If you set border-top: 1px solid black, the longhand properties (border-top-color, border-top-style, and border-top-width) are set instead.
The main difference between property and attributeStyleMap property is that, the style property will return a object, while the attributeStyleMap property will return a object.
Though the property itself is not writable, you could read and write inline styles through the object that it returns, just like through the object that returns via the style property.

SVGElementAutofocus.summary: The autofocus property of the interface contains a boolean value reflecting the autofocus HTML global attribute. It indicates whether the SVG element should be focused when the page loads or when the element becomes shown if the SVG element is inside a dialog or a popover.

remarks.para:
-
-
-Popover API

SVGElementBlur.summary: The SVGElement.blur() method removes keyboard focus from the current SVG element.

remarks.para:
- makes the element the current keyboard focus.
- a similar method for HTML elements.

SVGElementDataset.summary: The dataset read-only property of the interface provides read/write access to custom data attributes (data-*) on elements. It exposes a map of strings () with an entry for each data-* attribute.

remarks.para: For more information on the behavior of dataset, see .

-data-* SVG attributes
-Using data attributes

SVGElementError.summary: The error event is fired when an SVG element does not load properly or when an error occurs during script execution.

remarks.para: This basically implements the standard error DOM event.
This event is not cancelable.

SVGElementFocus.summary:
The SVGElement.focus() method sets focus on the specified SVG element, if it can be focused.
The focused element is the element that will receive keyboard and similar events by default.

remarks.para:
By default the browser will scroll the element into view after focusing it, and it may also provide visible indication of the focused element (typically by displaying a "focus ring" around the element).
Parameter options are provided to disable the default scrolling and force visible indication on elements.

- to remove the focus from an element.
- a similar method for HTML elements.

SVGElementLoad.summary: The load event fires on an SVGElement when it is loaded in the browser, e.g., in the DOM in the case of an embedded <svg>. It is basically the same as the standard load DOM event.

remarks.para: This event is not cancelable and does not bubble.

SVGElementNonce.summary: The nonce property of the interface returns the {{Glossary("Nonce", "nonce")}} that is used by Content Security Policy to determine whether a given fetch will be allowed to proceed.

remarks.para:
- a similar method for HTML elements.
-nonce global attribute
-Content Security Policy
-CSP: {{CSP("script-src")}}

SVGElementNonce.value: A String; the cryptographic nonce, or an empty string if no nonce is set.

SVGElementOwnerSVGElement.summary: The ownerSVGElement property of the interface reflects the nearest ancestor {{SVGElement("svg")}} element. null if the given element is the outermost <svg> element.

SVGElementStyle.summary:
The read-only style property of the interface returns the inline style of an element in the form of a live object.
This object can be used to get and set the inline styles of an element.

remarks.para:
-Using dynamic styling information
-
-
-

SVGElementStyle.value:
A live object.
NOTEEarlier versions of the specification returned a (from which is derived).
See the browser compatibility table for browser support information.Although the style property itself is read-only in the sense that you can't replace the CSSStyleProperties object, you can still assign to the style property directly, which is equivalent to assigning to its property. You can also modify the CSSStyleProperties object using the and methods.

SVGElementTabIndex.summary: The tabIndex property of the interface represents the tab order of the current SVG element.

remarks.para: Tab order is as follows:
Elements that are disabled do not participate in the tabbing order.

Values don't need to be sequential, nor must they begin with any particular value. They
may even be negative, though each browser trims very large values.

- a similar method for HTML elements.
-Accessibility of keyboard-navigable JavaScript widgets
-The HTML
tabindex
global attribute.

SVGElementViewportElement.summary: The viewportElement property of the interface represents the SVGElement which established the current viewport. Often the nearest ancestor svg element. null if the given element is the outermost <svg> element.

remarks.para: -: Retrieves the nearest ancestor <svg> element for the current SVG element.
